Award.AwardTitle: Regulation of Chromatin-associated Proteins by Ubiquitin Modification of Histones H2A and H2B

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
In eukaryotes, the genetic material DNA is complexed with proteins and packaged into chromatin. The proteins that organize the DNA are called histones. The interplay between the genetic information in DNA and the additional (or epigenetic) information conferred by the type of association with these histones determines cell fate. The long-term goal of this project is to understand how epigenetic information is interpreted by cellular machineries that instigate changes in gene expression to regulate growth and differentiation. One form of epigenetic information is the modification of histones by attachment of a small protein called ubiquitin. In organisms ranging from flies to human, histones H2A and H2B each can be modified with ubiquitin, but with different biological consequences. Whereas H2A ubiquitination is associated with gene silencing and DNA repair processes, H2B ubiquitination plays critical roles in active gene expression. How ubiquitin attached to H2A and H2B histones are interpreted as distinct signals that result in these different downstream effects is unknown. To address this knowledge gap, methods will be developed to obtain chemically homogeneous ubiquitin-H2A (or H2B) to identify proteins whose associations with chromatin are regulated by ubiquitin. A combination of biophysical and biochemical techniques will be used to characterize potential interactions between ubiquitin and histones and to investigate the functional significance of H2B ubiquitination in gene expression. Overall, this project will establish a new approach to study epigenetics and will provide mechanistic details as to how one type of epigenetic information regulates gene expression and ultimately cell fate.
Broader impacts: In addition to its scientific significance in the areas of epigenetics and gene expression, this project provides outstanding training opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students. Many aspects of these studies involve biochemical experiments that are well-suited for undergraduates who may have limited time as well as limited laboratory experience. The employment of a variety of biochemical, biophysical and cutting-edge proteomics technologies provide broad training for graduate students and postdocs. In addition, as part of the broader impact efforts, workshops will be provided to graduate students and postdocs on innovative scientific teaching methods and mentor training. Overall, this project will have a direct positive impact on tomorrow's science educators.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In human cells, the genetic material DNA is wrapped around histone proteins. Modifications on DNA and histones together give instructions to when and which genes are expressed during development and in response to the changing environment. Such a mechanism, referred to as epigenetics, is responsible for phenotypic differences of cells or organisms that have the same DNA sequences. This NSF award allowed us to develop tools to study the biochemical properties and functional significance of one type of epigenetic modification: histone ubiquitination. Interestingly, depending on where ubiquitin is attached to histones, the biological consequences can be active transcription, transcription repression, or DNA damage repair. How the ubiquitin signal leads to these varied responses are not well understood. 

 

During the funding period, we have developed chemical strategies that allow rapid, efficient and homogenous preparation of histones ubiquitinated at specific sites. These preparations further enabled us to: (1) characterize enzymes that remove ubiquitin from histones, i.e., “erasers”; and (2) identify proteins that recognize the ubiquitin modification on histones, i.e. “readers”. Mutations in many of these erasers and readers have been linked to cancers, such as uveal melanoma and leukemia. In addition, the methods we developed have enabled other researchers in the field to study structural and other aspects of histone ubiquitination.

 

This NSF award also provided training opportunities for over a dozen undergraduate students, graduate students and post-doc fellows, with an emphasis on developing the next generation of science educators. We have taught and implemented evidence-based scientific teaching philosophy and methods. We also provided mentorship and hands-on experience for the trainees to develop their teaching styles. Trainees also participated in outreach programs that bring scientific concepts into fifth-grade classrooms as well as the Summer Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) program. These activities provided valuable opportunities that are uncommon in our standard academic training regime. As a result, among the trainees, two graduate students and one post-doc fellow have obtained positions to be Assistant Professors in universities across the US, training future generations of burgeoning minds.
